results.title: Hanimex Rondette 400S 35mm colour slide projector
results.brief_description: “Hanimex Rondette 400S 35mm colour slide projector Made in New Zealand f2.8 projector 8.5mm 230 - 240 V 50CYC A.C. Only 60W Use 12V 50W Iodine Quartz Lamp. Made in New Zealand by Hanimex Manufacturing Ltd. Green guarantee sticker on the bottom: N.Z. No 37229 Housed in original cardboard box. Air New Zealand MELBOURNE destination tag stapled to top of the box. Purchased from Christchurch International Duty Free Shop. 3 slides: - Man in Traditional dress. ‘Taken on Board Rasa Sayang. Handwritten label: BL 23 - Test slide for Reflector Adjustment - Kodachrome transparency of 3 men performing in a band. Standard 36 Han-O-Matic Magazine original box with index printed on outside. Kindermann (Adapter Rachmen) original red cardboard box. 37 Kindermann Adapters for 110 slides. Made in West Germany. Three plastic 110 Film slide viewers Paperwork included: Kodacolour II Film Instructions Hanimex La Rondette 400S QI Instructions Hanimex Magazine Instructions Hanimex Guarantee card”

results.title: Walt Disney Movie Viewer
results.brief_description:
Walt Disney Mettoy Viewer c. 1960
The first Movie Viewer was made in the USA in 1973 by Fisher Price. The British version was made by the Mettoy company. The viewer used Super 8 film and the actual clips were short pieces from real cartoon films. No technology was required to operate the viewer, not even batteries. The hand crank enabled the operator to view the film at any speed with the ability to go forwards or backwards at will.

results.title:
The Family Law
script from season one, episode one, 2016
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-11. Screen Australia Showcase → MA-11-C01

results.media_note: Sorry, we aren't able to make images or video for this item available to the public online.

results.title: Magnaphonic 35mm projector
results.brief_description:
Magnaphonic 35mm projectors like these were used as a pair. During a screening, the projectionist seamlessly changed film rolls between projectors, loading all ‘even’ reels on one projector and ‘odd’ reels on the other projector.

This one was used in the small town of Tumbarumba, nestled in the shadow of the Snowy Mountains. From around 1959 until 1965, it was operated by William James Burnell Newman, who ran Valley Theatres. It’s representative of early 20th-century Australian cinema equipment and would’ve been used before TV kickstarted the demise of country theatres in the mid-60s.

constellations_primary.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_primary.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.
